para.text: Heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration inspectors hired by the State, a county, or other local subdivision, shall meet minimum standards that are established by the State Board.
The minimum standards established by the State Board are as follows:

The heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration inspector shall be licensed as a Maryland master, master restricted, or journeyman heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration contractor;

The heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration inspector shall hold a current Building Officials and Code Administrators International, Inc. (BOCA) certification in one of the following classifications: mechanical inspector, mechanical plans examiner, plumbing inspector, plumbing plans examiner, one- and two-family dwelling combination inspector, one- and two-family dwelling mechanical inspector, one- and two-family dwelling plumbing inspector; or
The heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration inspector shall:
Have at least 4 years experience as an inspector or mechanic in the mechanical building and construction trade including heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration, and

Pass a written examination prepared and administered by the State Board or prepared and administered by the county or local subdivision, provided the examination is approved by the State Board, and certified copies of all results are provided to the State Board.

Each heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration inspector shall attend, at least once a year, a refresher course to be conducted by the State Board or a course approved by the State Board and which is conducted by a county or local subdivision.

section.heading: Responsibility of Master, Master Restricted, or Limited Licensee.
section.text: A licensee may not use the licensee's license to obtain a permit or other authority to proceed from a governmental entity unless the licensee is:

para.text: Familiar with the design and purpose of the specific heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration work to be performed;
Available to direct and control all journeymen, apprentices, and others providing heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration services; and
Responsible for the work.
Definition. For purposes of this regulation, "license number" means the license registration certificate number that shows on the license document received by the individual licensee.
License Number on Vehicles.

Each vehicle that advertises heating, ventilation, air conditioning, or refrigeration services shall display the current category and license number of the master, master restricted, or limited licensed contractor who supervises and controls the work of that company in that particular area.

Each licensed heating, ventilation, air conditioning, or refrigeration master, master restricted, or limited contractor shall display the licensee's license category and license number on both sides of all vehicles primarily used by the licensee or under the licensee's supervision and control for the performance of heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration services.
A contractor's license category shall be indicated by the following prefixes:
.01 for a master license;
.02 for a master restricted license;
.06 for a limited license.
The license category and the license number shall be displayed on each vehicle in the following form:
Md.—HVAC—category prefix—license number;
Display of letters or numbers shall be at least 1-1/2 inches in height.

Each printed, audio, or video advertisement of any type, and all contracts shall reflect the license category and license number, in a manner as described in §B(4)(a) of this regulation, of the current licensee to be responsible for the work.
The Board may restore the license of an individual who has failed to renew the license for any reason if the individual:
Applies for restoration within 90 days of expiration of the license;
Otherwise is entitled to be licensed; and
Pays to the Board the renewal fee.
An individual who fails to seek the restoration of a license within 90 days of expiration of the license shall:
File a written letter with the Board providing:
The reasons the individual permitted the license to expire,
An explanation for the individual's failure to file a timely application for license renewal or restoration,
A statement of the individual's employment and job duties since the license expiration, and
Any documentation to support the individual's claims; and
Appear in person before the Board to show good and valid cause why the individual's license should be restored, if the Board requires the individual to do so.
The Board may:
Restore an expired license of the applicant under this regulation if the applicant:
Is otherwise entitled to be licensed, and
Pays to the Board all past due renewal fees, and any applicable reinstatement and late fees;
Require the applicant to pay the applicable examination fees, and take and successfully pass the written examination required for the license previously held by the applicant; or

Consider the applicant as having never been licensed, in accordance with Business Regulation Article, §9A-309(e)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland, thus requiring the filing of a new application and complying with Business Regulation Article, §9A-302, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Time to Request Formal Hearing on Denial.
section.text: If an application for a license is denied by the Board, the applicant, within 30 days from the date on the notice of the Board's decision, may request a formal hearing, conducted in accordance with Business Regulation Article, §9A-311, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Renewal of a Lower License Category.

para.text: A master, master restricted, or limited licensee:
May elect to renew a current license under a lower category, if the original license held by the licensee is forfeited;

Who has renewed and received a license pursuant to §A(1) of this regulation, is required to requalify for the higher category of license previously held by taking and passing the appropriate examination administered by the Board in accordance with Business Regulation Article, §9A-304, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Board may waive the examination requirement in §A(2) of this regulation, for a licensee who:
Renewed a license under §A(1) of this regulation; and

Had obtained the higher category license previously held by taking and passing the appropriate examination administered by the Board in accordance with Business Regulation Article, §9A-304, Annotated Code of Maryland.

Before an HVACR apprentice may be examined for a license as an HVACR journeyman, the apprentice shall complete at least 6,000 hours of training in providing heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration services under the direction and control of a licensed HVACR contractor. The training shall be over a period of at least 4 years, while licensed as a Maryland HVACR apprentice.
It is recommended that the study, instruction, training, and experience include the following areas:
Installation of HVACR equipment including:
Determining location of exterior and interior equipment including condensers, thermostat, humidistat, exhaust piping, and duct work;
Preparing equipment foundation/base to install anchors, equipment, and vibration isolator pads;
Determining type and mounting system required for equipment, layout, and routing of condensate drain;
Installing air, water and evaporative cooled condensers, evaporative cooler, air-handling units, gas and oil furnaces, heat pumps, and baseboard heat;
Installing humidifiers, electronic air cleaners, thermostats, and humidistats; and

Installing and filling a hydronic system including a circulator pump, three-way diverter valve, automatic feeder, expansion tank, zone valves, air vent, pressure relief valve, booster fan, condensate pump, water pump, gas valve, and primary safety control;
Duct systems including:
Being able to provide basic design of a duct system and determine adequacy of the existing or designed duct system;
Installing with accessories round metal duct, rectangular metal duct, rigid fiberglass duct, plenum, duct liner, and duct wrap;
Installing manual air-flow damper, register, grill, fire damper, barometric damper, powered damper with actuator, factory-fabricated filter box, and vent damper;
Being able to modify an existing plenum and existing duct; and
Being able to fabricate a rectangular trunk line duct, plenum, transition, elbow, offset, sled with turning vanes, floor pan, and filter sled;
Diagnostic procedures including troubleshooting:
Air-conditioning system, AC system with electric heat, heat pump system, heat pump with fossil fuel heat;
Gas pack, gas furnace, electric furnace, oil furnace, and hydronic system; and
Cooling-tower system, chilled-water system, and evaporative cooler;
Adjustment of components including gas pressure, pilot flame, pilot igniter, direct spark igniter, burner oil system, burner air on gas furnaces, and burner primary air on oil furnaces;
Installation of piping and tubing including:
Determination of layout and size of refrigerant tubing;
Determination of the type and location of fittings and in-line components;
Connection of pipe using a threaded joint and a cemented joint;
Connection of tubing using a compression fitting, flare fitting, soft solder, and brazing;

Pipe and tubing insulation and covering, refrigeration line solenoid valve, in-line or angle hand valve, suction line accumulator, suction/liquid line heat exchanger, liquid receiver, fixed restriction/thermostatic expansion metering device, liquid/suction line filter-dryer, sight glass, pressure-regulator valve, head pressure control valve, check valve, and access valve; and
Vibration isolator in refrigerant line, precharged factory line set, tubing and pipe clamps and supports, and evaporator condensate drain line;
Placement of HVACR systems in operation including:
Leak test system, set belt tension if applicable, adjust condenser water-flow controls, test for gas leaks;
Measuring air flow at register, measuring relative humidity, adjusting humidistat, calibrating thermostat, and setting heat anticipator;
Adjusting fan speed for correct CFM output, adjusting fresh air intake, adjusting bypass damper, and adjusting relief damper;
Checking safety drain in attic installation, checking humidifier water feed and drain, checking aquastat for proper setting and operation, and checking static pressure at fan discharge;

Maintenance and repair of systems including replacing an HVAC timer delay relay, control switch, gas valve, pilot safety switch, glow coil assembly, thermocouple or thermopile, and flame sensing electronic sensing device.
The Journey examination will include questions based upon basic knowledge in the areas listed in §C of this regulation.

An applicant who has successfully completed the licensing examination shall apply for licensure, including payment of all applicable fees, within 1 year of successfully completing the licensing examination in order for the applicant's test results to remain valid. All applicants who have successfully completed the licensing examination more than 1 year before the effective date of this section shall apply for licensure not later than July 31, 1999.

An applicant for a license, filed pursuant to Business Regulation Article, §9A-306(e), Annotated Code of Maryland, authorizing the Board to issue a journeyman license to an applicant who has successfully completed an applicable apprentice program approved by the Apprenticeship and Training Council, shall have completed the apprentice program within 2 years of the date the journeyman license application is filed.

A licensee shall undertake to provide heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services only if the licensee is qualified by training, education, and experience to provide the required services.

A licensee shall maintain appropriate insurance covering any heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration service the licensee provides. Insurance provided by an employer does not satisfy the insurance requirements of Business Regulation Article, §9A-402, Annotated Code of Maryland, if a licensee provides heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, or refrigeration services outside the scope of employment with the insured person or business entity.
If an applicant or licensee receives from the Board a written communication requesting a response, the applicant or licensee shall respond in writing within 30 days of the date of the mailing.
The Board shall send a written communication by first-class mail to the last address furnished to the Board by the applicant or licensee.
It is the responsibility of an applicant or licensee to notify the Board in writing if there has been a change in an applicant’s or licensee’s address.
Failure to respond as required by this regulation may be considered by the Board to be a violation of Business Regulation Article, §9A-310(a)(1)(xii), Annotated Code of Maryland.
